ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was exposed to a lot of plays by different authors, and was really given the opportunity to focus on my dramatic writing.
How plays work, how to read plays, how to write scenes, plays, etc.

Reading a lot of famous plays (which was honestly, pretty fun) and our workshopping sessions helped give me some insight into how to construct a play in broader strokes. I did not really get a sense of the smaller, more minute details like crafting believable lines and dialogues. But I guess that kind of stuff only comes with practice.
You gain a sense of how a playwright conceptualizes what they write about.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is really great for someone who wants to study drama, or who is looking to improve their creative writing skills. I think the syllabus is really good, however sometimes the workload is heavy when you have to read 2 plays and also create a short scene for class, in addition to anything else.

There was VERY little feedback from the instructor in this course. Even after the semester is over, I have 0 clue what my grade is or truly how I performed in the class. The compliments are spare, which is how he does things, but really the feedback is spare as well.

Strengths: Prof. Margulies obviously, the workshop focus, and a great selection of readings

Weaknesses: Not many formal check-in points to see how my writing is going or how I am doing in the class, I think workshopping pieces in breakout rooms also would have been better than doing them as a whole class

The course was mainly talking about plays. It felt much more like a reading group than a writing group. I wish I had gotten a clearer traditional toolbox for writing. The mini prompts each week were very fruitful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Utilizing breakout rooms would have been especially nice for a workshop class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this to someone who is interested at all in plays, dramatic writing, or in theater in general. It is a bit of work, but the plays are really good, and there aren't that many opportunities to just focus on your creative writing, and to have it workshopped by others.
Anyone at all interested in plays and writing them should certainly take this class.

I recommend it because hes a very brilliant writer and the weekly exercises are great/ the syllabus is great but I dont recommend it in terms of teaching style because I really didnt feel I got individual feedback although the class was only 12 people
Absolutely! If you are new to playwriting or an old friend to the form, this course with Prof. Margulies is a must.
I would take it if you already know how to write plays. If you are brand new to dramatic writing, the course doesn't provide a succinct outline.
